International Center for Materials Nanoarchitectonics (WPI-MANA) National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS) Namiki 1-1 Tsukuba Ibaraki 305-0044 Japan ⁎⁎ Corresponding authors at: School of Physics and Technology, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, Shandong, China School of Physics and Technology University of Jinan Jinan Shandong 250022 China Layered double hydroxides (LDHs), a class of anionic clays consisting of brucite-like host layers and interlayer anions, have been widely investigated in the last decade due to their promising applications in many areas such as catalysis, ion separation and adsorption. Owing to the highly tunable composition and uniform distribution of metal cations in the brucite-like layers, as well as the facile exchangeability of intercalated anions, LDHs can be modified and functionalized to form various nanostructures/composites through versatile processes such as anion intercalation and exfoliation, decoration of nanoparticles, self-assembly with other two-dimensional (2D) materials, and controlled growth on conductive supports (e.g., nanowire arrays, nanotubes, 3D foams). In this article, we briefly review the recent advances on both the LDH nanostructures and functionalized composites toward the applications in energy conversion, especially for water oxidation. Graphical abstract Layered double hydroxides (LDHs), and their heterogeneous structures functionalized with 0D, 1D, 2D and 3D materials, are promising electrocatalysts for water oxidation. The design strategies, synthetic approaches, and electrocatalytic performances are reviewed. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Layered double hydroxide Energy conversion Water splitting Functionalization 1 Introduction The global energy crisis and environmental pollution have become two fatal issues for the sustainable development. Exploring the renewable energy alternatives to replace the conventional fossil fuels is considered one of the most promising ways to solve these problems, and have attracted tremendous interest [1,2]. Among them, hydrogen (H2) is promising as a clean energy source, which could be produced through electrochemical water splitting in large scale [3,4]. However, compared with cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the sluggish kinetics of anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) has been a major bottleneck in the overall water splitting process because the evolution of oxygen (O2) involves a 4-electron transfer process to form one molecule [1,5–7]. This uphill reaction requires a large overpotential typically operating at a cell voltage of 1.8–2.0 V, which is much higher than the thermodynamic value of 1.23 V [1,5–8]. To reduce the overpotential, many electrocatalysts for both OER and HER have been exploited [1,2,5]. So far, the most effective electrocatalysts for OER and HER are unexceptionally based on precious metals such as Ir, Ru and Pt. However, the scarcity and high cost of these precious metals limit industry-scale applications [1,5,9]. To tackle this challenge, great efforts have been devoted to exploring non-precious metal electrocatalysts. Among the candidate materials, layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have shown the intriguing electrocatalytic performance [1,10]. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs), a class of anionic clays, were first discovered in 1842. Nevertheless, the chemical formula [Mg6Al2(OH)16]CO3⋅4H2O had not been exactly depicted until 1915 [11]. In general, LDHs represent a large family of layered hydroxides consisting of positively charged host layers, charge-balancing anions, and interlayer water molecules. The general formula of LDHs could be described as [M2+ 1- x M3+ x (OH)2][A n − x/n ∙mH2O] (M2+ and M3+ are divalent and trivalent metal ions, respectively; x is in the range of 0.2–0.33; A n− is an anion) [12–14]. The structure is schematically shown in Fig. 1 [12]. In addition, the composition (the metal ions, stoichiometric coefficient (x), exchangeable anions in the guest layer) and the interlayer spacing can be readily tuned, which enables them to possess more attractive features for functionalization [15–17]. LDHs can be facilely synthesized by well-established synthetic protocols, for example, co-precipitation and homogenous precipitation by urea hydrolysis, which can be scaled up for industrial production [14,18,19]. Due to the unique physical and chemical properties, LDHs have been widely applied in many fields, including adsorbents [20], antimicrobial agents [21], additives in polymers, magnetic materials, and precursors for functional materials [15,22]. In particular, LDHs and their derivatives have been used as electrocatalysts such as alcohol oxidation [23], OER [1,24,25], HER [26,27], and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [28–30]. In the past few years, the publications relating to the electrocatalytic applications of transition metals based LDH materials present a rapid increasing trend, as shown in Fig. 2 . The advances in the syntheses and applications of LDHs have been reviewed by other groups [12,15,31–33]. However, there are few review papers focusing on the electrocatalytic applications of transition metal LDHs-based materials. Thus, it is necessary and timely to survey the recent developments of LDHs and their functionalized forms toward electrocatalytic applications. In this review article, we summarize the recent progress in the design and synthesis of functionalized LDHs materials particularly for the electrocatalysis (Table 1 ). The merits of LDHs and their functionalized derivatives as electrocatalysts are highlighted and the structure-property correlations are discussed. The major challenge in the electrocatalytic application lies in the need to simultaneously improve the electrocatalytic activity and to simplify the fabrication process of these functionalized LDHs materials. This review article provides useful insights into current approaches to develop robust and promising electrocatalysts based on functionalized LDHs materials. Finally, we also analyze the potential and propose future direction of developing functionalized LDHs for electrocatalysis. 2 Transition metal LDHs as electrocatalysts With the world's fast-growing population, the global energy demand is expected to reach 27 terawatt (TW) by 2040, and thus the supply of clean and affordable energy is a critical challenge nowadays [34–36]. As aforementioned, electrochemical water splitting is a promising way to be used in the energy storage and conversion [35]. However, the development of highly active and stable electrocatalysts composed of earth-abundant materials is necessary to achieve the highly efficient and economical water splitting [2,35]. In this aspect, the unique composition and structure of LDHs are suitable for designing the catalytic properties for the water splitting. Firstly, the brucite-like layers containing one or more cations offer abundant basic sites used as heterogeneous catalysts. Secondly, the cations within brucite-like layers are uniformly distributed at atomic level leading to high catalytic activity [35]. Thirdly, the larger interlayer distance affords remarkable electrochemically accessible surface areas to facilitate the electrochemical catalysis [37–39]. Traditionally, LDH materials are synthesized by co-precipitation with a typical composition of Mg and Al, which are considered inert for electrocatalytic applications. Recently, new processes such as homogeneous precipitation have been developed to synthesize highly crystalline MgAl LDHs. It then extends to incorporate transitional metals in the Al3+-containing LDHs, taking advantage of the amphoteric property of Al3+ [40]. However, for the purpose to pursuing high electrocatalytic activity, the exploration of protocols to synthesize LDHs of all transition metals, has become a topic with increasing importance. In this regard, our group has first developed a novel topochemical approach, in which the synthesis and exfoliation of a series of transition metal based LDHs, such as Co2+-Fe3+ LDHs [40], Co2+-Co3+ LDHs [41], have been demonstrated. Since then, the synthesis of transition metal based LDHs targeting their application as electrocatalysts are boosting in a very fast pace. Li et al. developed a facile room-temperature electrochemical approach to fabricate various Fe-containing LDH (MFe LDHs, M = Ni, Co and Li) hierarchical nanoarrays on the surface of conducting substrates within hundreds of seconds [42]. Among these nanostructures, NiFe LDH nanoplatelet arrays on Ni foam exhibited optimal electrocatalytic activity with an overpotential of 224 mV (at 10 mA cm−2) and long-term stability (2%–5% increase of overpotential after testing 10 h) for OER in 1 M KOH, as shown in Fig. 3 . Furthermore, the MFe LDH nanoplatelet arrays could be universally used as electrocatalysts toward oxidation of other small fuel molecules (N2H4, CH3OH and C2H5OH). Zhang et al. reported a core-shell structured NiCo LDHs prepared by a facile route from a brucite-like Ni-Co hydroxide precursor with iodine as a topotactic oxidizing agent [43]. The results showed that the brucite-like NiCo precursor exhibited lower electrocatalytic activity compared with NiCo LDHs in neutral electrolyte. This could be ascribed to the Co3+ hydroxide in the inner core induced by the partial topotactic transformation. Zou et al. synthesized ZnCo LDHs by co-precipitation reaction at room temperature and achieved the electrocatalytic performance with an overpotential of 340 mV in 0.1 M KOH [44]. The mechanism was ascribed to the relatively open structure of ZnCo LDHs offering more accessible electrocatalytically active Co sites, fast diffusion of reactants/products, and even rapid photon-coupled electron transfer (PCET). Herein, the role of the redox-inactive Zn2+ ions was suggested to provide the stability and improve electron transfer pathways during catalysis [44,45]. The effect of Al3+ ions on the electrochemical property was also confirmed by Khan et al. through comparing the activity of NiCoAl LDHs, NiCo LDHs, and CoAl LDHs [46]. In order to further improve the electrochemical performance of LDHs, many efforts have been devoted to studying the effects of transition metal by tuning the elemental species and stoichiometries [1,47–49]. The results demonstrated that the electroactivity of transition metals Ni, Co, Mo, and Fe was in the sequence of Mn < Fe < Co < Ni (Fig. 4 ) [1,47–51]. In addition, the OER activity was discovered to be strongly dependent on the molar ratios of Co/Fe in LDHs [1]. The ternary transition metal LDHs were also found to show excellent OER activity than the corresponding binary transition metal ones. Lu et al. reported that the ternary NiFeMn LDHs synthesized by co-precipitation reaction showed superior OER activity [52]. Ternary FeNiCo LDHs prepared by co-precipitation method also exhibited superior electrocatalytic activity toward water oxidation in alkaline solution because of the suitable electronic structures as well as reduced charge transfer resistance [53]. Besides the effect from transition metal cations, interlayer anions also play an important role in the OER activity via tuning the interlayer distance [1,54]. Xu et al. reported that the OER activity of NiFe LDHs was enhanced by expanding the interlayer spacing from 7.69 Å to 8.04 Å through replacing CO3 2− with NO3 − [55]. Huter et al. examined the effect of interlayer anions on NiFe LDH nanosheets toward water oxidation activity and illustrated that the Brønsted or Lewis basicity of anions played a significant role in the electrochemical activity [56]. Nejati et al. synthesized vanadate (VO4) and molybdate (MoO4) intercalated ZnFe LDHs by co-precipitation methods [57]. VO4-LDHs exhibited superior OER activity than that of MoO4-LDH and NO3-LDH, confirming the important role of anions toward electrochemical water oxidation. In addition to the above approaches involving the tuning of the composition and interlayer spacing, exfoliating the bulk LDH materials to nanosheets is another effective way to improve the electrocatalytic activity. Song et al. prepared the exfoliated single-layer nanosheets of NiFe LDHs and demonstrated higher OER activity even than commercial IrO2 in the alkaline solution due to the increase in active site density and conductivity [58]. Our group has recently reported an important insight into the conductivity of LDHs including bulk crystals and exfoliated nanosheets [59]. It was revealed that the interlayer species and gallery height of LDHs are highly associated with the hydroxyl ion conduction. Moreover, the surface of LDH nanosheets is more accessible to water molecules than the interlayer galleries of LDH platelets, resulting in the exceptionally high OH− conductivity of exfoliated single-layer nanosheets. Li et al. also synthesized single-layer CoAl LDH with CO3 2− counterions by ethylene-glycol assisted solvothermal method, which showed high specific surface area and high efficiency in electrocatalytic oxygen evolution [19]. Furthermore, the intrinsic catalytic activity could be enhanced by using single-layer nanosheets. For example, NiV LDH nanosheets with a thickness of 0.9 nm were synthesized by a simple hydrothermal method by Fan et al. [60]. The excellent OER activity in alkaline solution was originated from the high intrinsic catalytic activity due to the good conductivity, facile electron transfer and abundant active sites in the monolayer structure. On the other hand, the intrinsic activity could also be enhanced by introducing the defects in the catalytic active sites [61]. For example, Wang et al. synthesized ultrathin CoFe nanosheets from bulk CoFe LDHs by the dry exfoliation and then introduced the multiple vacancies (including O, Co, and Fe vacancies) into the nanosheets by Ar plasma etching method (Fig. 5 ) [62]. The superior OER activity was achieved due to the increased number of exposed active sites and the formation of multiple vacancies in the as-exfoliated nanosheets. Furthermore, the long-term stability is another important factor that impacts the practical application prospect of LDH-based electrocatalysts. It is well known that the catalysts might be peeled off from the supports by the continuously generated bubbles during the OER process, which will significantly degrade the stability of electrocatalysts [63]. In-situ growth is considered one of the most effective approaches to improve the stability of LDH based materials as electrocatalysts [64–66]. Yang et al. reported that the ultrathin NiCoFe LDH nanoplates directly grown on a cobalt-based nanowire array showed excellent stability in alkaline media as OER catalyst, retaining structure and catalytic activity for 10 h under a current density of 300 mA cm−2 [65]. Therefore, it is of great interest to develop new synthetic processes [64–66], design amorphous structures [67], or combine LDH with other robust materials (such as graphene), which will be discussed below. In brief, utilizing the feature of transition metals LDH materials, the electrocatalytic activity could be drastically enhanced by tuning transition metals, adjusting the molar ratios of metal elements, expanding the interlayer spacing through anion exchange, exfoliating bulk LDHs to form nanosheets, and introduction of defects. However, the low electrical conductivity of LDHs is still one of major issues limiting the application as electrocatalysts, and thus many efforts have been made to solve this problem by further functionalization (see below) [37,38]. 3 LDH-based heterogeneous structures as electrocatalysts Although LDH materials in their own right have been proved to show promising electrocatalytic activity as reviewed in the above section, it still suffers from intrinsic drawbacks of LDHs, such as low electrical conductivity, to limit the catalytic performance for practical applications [29,33,37]. Seh et al. have reviewed the electrocatalysis both from theory and experiment to provide deep insights into materials design and summarized the two typical strategies for improving the activity of an electrocatalyst system as shown in Fig. 6 [68]. The strategies solve the problem from the intrinsic and extrinsic aspects including: (1) enhancing the intrinsic activity of each active site and (2) increasing the number of active sites (e.g., through increased loading or improved catalyst structuring to expose more active sites per gram). These strategies can be simultaneously combined together to greatly improve the electrocatalytic activity. Most importantly, it is noticeable that the activity difference originating from intrinsic modulation is far greater than that of extrinsic modification [35,68,69]. Since the discussion in the second section about using LDHs alone as electrocatalysts mainly belongs to tune the intrinsic activity of LDHs, the following part will devote to elucidate the extrinsic activity modulation. 3.1 0D nanoparticles decorated LDHs as electrocatalysts One of the established methods to improve the electrical conductivity of LDHs is to decorate the surface of LDHs with conductive nanoparticles. Metal nanoparticles are widely used to combine with other materials to form heterojunctions, facilitating the electron transfer in catalytic process. It is also beneficial to increase the heterogeneous interaction between the metal nanoparticles and LDH layers [23,70–72]. Mignani et al. fabricated Au nanoparticles-NiAl LDH (AuNPs-NiAl LDH) heterostrucutures by one-step electrosynthesis onto the Pt electrode surface and examined the electrochemical behavior toward the oxidation of methanol in basic media [71]. The enhanced electrocatalytic performance could be ascribed to the following reasons: (1) the increase in electron transfer efficiency due to the increased electrical conductivity; (2) the more efficient contact in the heterostructure between Au nanoparticles and NiAl LDHs. The effect of LDHs on the elctrocatalytic activity of metal nanoparticles was also studied by Taei et al. [73], where the LDH/AuNPs/GCE was fabricated by electrodeposition of Au nanoparticles (AuNPs) on a glassy carbon electrode (GCE), and followed by MgCaFe LDH coating. The enhanced long-term stability could be ascribed to adsorbed OH species at the surface provided by LDHs to prevent the poisoning effect of intermediate species on Au nanoparticles. All these described merits of LDHs and metal nanoparticles were useful to enhance OER activity through the formation of heterostructures. In this regard, NiFe LDH ultrathin nanosheets decorated with Ni nanoparticles (Ni NP/NiFe LDH) were synthesized by a one-step hydrothermal method and characterized as superior electrocatalysts for water oxidation in alkaline solution (Fig. 7 ) [70]. As mentioned above, the high performance was attributed to the highly conductive Ni nanoparticles reducing the charge transfer resistance while LDHs offering the highly exposed catalytically active sites, as well as the synergistic effects arising from the intimate contact of metallic Ni nanoparticles and NiFe LDH. On the other hand, the morphology and size of metal nanoparticles supported on LDHs also substantially influenced the catalytic activity [32,74]. Therefore, the design of metal nanoparticles is very important. Recently, Lee et al. synthesized Pt nanoparticles adsorbed on the surface of delaminated MgAl LDH nanosheets by electrostatic assembly method (ex-LDH-Pt) or supported on LDHs by in-situ reduction method (in-LDH-Pt) [75]. The LDH nanosheets effectively provide the large-area double sides of hydroxide functionality to adsorb the Pt nanoparticles and facilitate the fast diffusion rate of the reactants into the catalyst surface, resulting in the higher catalytic activity. Zhang et al. also synthesized single-atom Au supported on NiFe LDH (sAu/NiFe LDH) by a simple electrochemical deposition method, as shown in Fig. 8 [76]. Herein, single-atom Au changed the charge distribution of active Fe atoms by transferring electrons to LDH, resulting in the enhanced OER catalytic performance. This strategy is becoming a facile way to develop new types of catalyst structures with metal nanoparticles supported on LDHs. In addition to metal nanoparticles, non-metal nanoparticles were also anchored on LDH materials to improve the electrocatalytic performance. Recently, carbon quantum dots (CQD) were incorporated into ultrathin NiFe LDH nanoplates to form hybrids as a highly efficient electrocatalyst for water oxidation in alkaline solution [77]. The CQDs with a size of about 5 nm were synthesized in one-step electrochemical approach. They were embedded on the ultrathin (∼ 1 nm) NiFe LDH nanoplates with variable lateral size of 5–200 nm through two-step solvothermal reaction, as depicted in Fig. 9 . The higher OER activity was mainly attributed to the formation of the strong bonding and interaction of NiFe LDH phase with CQDs, which facilitate the charge transport between them. Moreover, LDHs could even be modified by metal hydroxide nanoparticles to improve the OER performance. Valdez et al. reported the synthesis of CoFe LDHs decorated with CoFe hydroxide nanoparticles and the application in water oxidation reaction at neutral solution [78]. The enhanced OER activity was attributed to a synergistic effect between the CoFe hydroxide nanoparticles and CoFe LDHs, i.e., the electrons from iron or cobalt of the nanoparticles interacting with the electrons of CoFe LDH surface, resulting in the decrease of the overpotential for OER. 3.2 1D Nanowires/nanotubes supported LDHs as electrocatalysts Despite that LDHs decorated with the nanoparticles showed excellent electrocatalytic activity, great effort is still needed to combine new components to further improve the performance. One-dimensional materials could be one of the alternatives to hybrid with LDHs toward the development of highly efficient electrocatalysts. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are usually referred to as one-dimensional conductors exhibiting good electrocatalytic activities, and helpful to enhance activities by functionalization or doping [79,80]. Huang et al. successfully assembled exfoliated CoAl LDH nanosheets with CNTs to form hybrids via electrostatic force while effectively preventing the exfoliated LDHs from stacking together [81]. Later, Gong et al. reported the synthesis of ultrathin NiFe LDH nanoplates on mildly oxidized multiwalled CNTs through a three-step process, as depicted in Fig. 10 [38]. The OER activity was investigated in basic solutions with different concentrations, concluding that the high OER activity was mainly attributed to the NiFe LDH phase and the underlying CNT network served to enhance the electron transport. LDHs grown on the surface of metal oxide was also investigated. Similarly, they displayed excellent OER property by virtue of the construction of heterostructures to improve the catalytic performance derived from the synergistic effect. For example, amorphous NiFe LDH film covered on CuO nanorod arrays was synthesized by Zhou et al. [82]. The resulting core-shell heterostructure demonstrated excellent OER performance in 10 M KOH solution with an overpotential of 0.29 V at the current density of 50 mA cm−2 with the Tafel slope of 60 mV/dec. Additionally, the long-term stability was proved by maintaining a steady current density of 50 mA cm−2 for at least 35 h with the negligible decline in catalytic activity. This superior OER performance was originated from the synergistic effect between amorphous NiFe LDH film and CuO nanorod arrays. In a word, the formation of heterogeneous structure could strongly facilitate the charge transport between LDHs and 1D nanomaterials, which was beneficial to the OER activity. Therefore, 1D nanowires/nanotubes supported LDHs could take full advantage of the synergistic effect of these two materials to achieve the optimization toward water oxidation reaction. 3.3 LDH nanosheets assembled with other 2D materials As aforementioned, LDH nanosheets could significantly improve the electrocatalytic performance due to the superhigh specific surface area [12,83–85]. The exposure of transition metal atoms on the sheet surface could facilitate the redox reaction owing to the fast proton-coupled electron transfer process and rapid diffusion of the reactants [85]. However, the exfoliated LDH nanosheets were prone to aggregate together, in addition to the insulating and unstable nature [85,86]. Therefore, LDHs were usually assembled with other 2D materials to overcome the above drawbacks for the enhancement of electrocatalytic activity. Graphene (G), graphene oxide (GO), and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) were considered to be ideal 2D carbon materials with large surface area, good electrical conductivity, and atomic thickness [87–89]. Hence, much work has been carried out by coupling LDHs with graphene, GO or rGO to achieve higher electrocatalytic properties [90,91]. The exfoliated NiFe LDH nanosheets were alternately stacked with GO as well as rGO to form superlattice-like hybrids for efficient splitting of water [85]. The heterostructured Ni2/3Fe1/3-GO exhibited an excellent OER efficiency with a small overpotential of about 230 mV and Tafel slope of 42 mV/decade. More significantly, the activity was further enhanced to achieve an overpotential of 210 mV and Tafel slope of 40 mV/decade by combination of Ni2/3Fe1/3 LDH nanosheets with rGO (Ni2/3Fe1/3-rGO) (Fig. 11 ). The superior activities can be explained as follows. The enhancement of electrochemical active surface was obtained by the incorporation of GO/rGO, preventing the aggregation of LDH nanosheets. The direct and interfacial contact between LDH nanosheets and GO/rGO at a molecular scale in the superlattice produced effective synergistic actions for the OER process. Moreover, GO/rGO may serve as a supporting matrix to enhance the mechanical strength and stability, resulting in the better durability. Using a similar method, our group also explored the face-to-face heteroassembly of unilamellar NiMn (Ni/Mn with a molar ratio of 2:1) LDH nanosheets with conductive rGO at an alternating sequence and obtained a small overpotential of 0.26 V and a Tafel slope of 46 mV/decade [24]. The results further confirmed that the superlattice structure could ideally facilitate the migration/transfer of the charge and reactants due to the synergistic effect arising from molecular hybridization. The difference in catalytic activity between NiFe-rGO and NiMn-rGO additionally manifested the favorable effect of Fe content on the electrochemical catalysis [45,92]. Although rGO was more conductive than GO and thus more effective in achieving higher electrochemical catalysis, the electrocatalyst based on GO was still worthy investigating due to the simple fabrication process. NiFe-GO LDH was synthesized by intercalating GO into NiFe LDH via anion exchange process. The composite showed superior electrocatalytic property with an overpotential of 220 mV and Tafel slope of 40 mV/decade. Again, the reasons could be attributed to the strong interaction between FeNi double hydroxide layers and the graphene layers at the molecular level [89]. Nitrogen-doped graphene frameworks (NGF) were also employed as a mesoporous substrate for the in situ growth and decoration of nanometer-sized NiFe LDHs (nNiFe LDHs) to form spatially confined hybrids (Fig. 12 ) [93]. The as-prepared nNiFe LDH/NGF structure showed an overpotential of 337 mV and Tafel slope of 45 mV/decade, which even outperformed the precious Ir/C catalyst. The superior electrocatalytic activity was attained due to the highly conductive and unique mesoporous scaffold of NGF with moderately active sites. The porous framework delivered a large accessible surface and vast stacked interstices to provide free channels for electrolyte ion insertion/extraction and gas diffusion. The introduction of nNiFe LDHs effectively moderated the surface character and created abundant highly active sites. As aforementioned, the defects in the catalytic sites played a positive role in the electrocatalytic activity. The defective graphene was assembled with the exfoliated NiFe LDH nanosheet to form a heterostructure as a binfucntional electrocatalyst for overall water splitting by Jia and coworkers (Fig. 13 ) [94]. They reported an extremely high electrocatalytic activity for OER in an alkaline solution with an overpotential of 210 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and Tafel slope of 52 mV/decade, as well as the HER with an overpotential of 115 mV at a current density of 20 mA cm−2. The bifunctional catalyst could achieve a current density of 20 mA cm−2 by a voltage of only 1.5 V for overall water splitting. The mechanism could be ascribed to the synergetic effects of highly exposed metal atoms and carbon defects. In addition to the carbon-based 2D materials, other 2D conductors were also employed to improve the electrocatalytic activities of LDHs [95]. Typically, 2D early transition metal carbides/carbonitrides (MXene) possess some desirable properties such as hydrophilic surface and metallic conductivity [96,97], which became a good candidate to assemble with LDHs for the electrochemical application. Yu et al. fabricated hierarchical NiFe LDH/Ti3C2 MXene nanohybrids by ionic hetero-assembly of interconnected porous network of NiFe LDH nanoplates on Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets toward the superior OER activity, as schematically shown in Fig. 14 [95]. The strong interfacial interaction and electronic coupling with prominent charge-transfer between NiFe LDH and Ti3C2 MXene could improve the structural stability and electrical conductivity of the nanohybrids, resulting in the noticeable acceleration of the redox process of NiFe LDH for OER. In summary, the combination of 2D materials could enhance the intrinsic activity of the exfoliated LDH nanosheets, preventing the self-stacking. Furthermore, the heterostructure of LDHs and 2D materials could improve the conductivity, promote the electron transfer and accelerate mass transfer, resulting in the enhanced OER performance of the electrocatalysts based on LDH nanosheets and other 2D materials. 3.4 LDH nanoplates grown on 3D supports 3D architectures have some unique advantages compared with 2D structures, such as more accessible electrochemical active surface area, fast electrolyte penetration, and facilitated electron transport [98–100]. Therefore, LDHs were also grown on 3D supports to form 3D architectures to achieve the synergistic properties. Nickel foam, as one of the most common supports, was used to grow NiFe LDH nanoplates to form LDH based 3D film by Lu et al. through a simple hydrothermal method, as depicted in Fig. 15 [39]. The OER performance in 0.1 M KOH solution was demonstrated with an overpotential of 280 mV at current density of 30 mA cm−2 and Tafel slope of 50 mV/decade. The underlying mechanism could be similar to aforementioned reasons that: (1) the directly grown catalyst layer on conductive supports eliminates the need for polymer binders, resulting in the efficient electron transport through the entire electrode; (2) 3D architectural electrode possesses a much larger surface area, leading to a high density of active sites for OER; (3) 3D architecture facilitates the electrolyte diffusion to favor the OER performance. NiFe LDH nanoplates were also grown on Fe foam by a facile room-temperature galvanic replacement reaction (GRR) method to form 3D electrocatalytic electrode, which was schematically shown in Fig. 16 [101]. In this work, the effects of the ratio of Ni/Fe and the intercalated anions on the final catalytic activities were systematically investigated. It was revealed that the larger Fe/Ni ratio and NO3 − anions could result in higher electrocatalytic activity due to the partial-charge transfer activation effect of Fe on Ni and the larger interlayer spacing. Indeed, NiFe-NO3 LDH/Fe foam exhibited the best OER activity that only required a small overpotential of 210 mV to deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH solution with a small Tafel slope of 40.4 mV/decade. Carbon clothes were also employed as a kind of flexibly conductive supports to fabricate LDH based 3D structures, showing good electrochemical activity [102,103]. NiCo LDH nanoarrays vertically assembled on carbon fiber papers (NiCo LDH-NA) were successfully synthesized using hydrothermal method by Yu et al. [104]. The fabrication process for NiCo LDH-NA and control sample NiCo LDH microspheres (NiCo LDH-MS) was schematically drawn in Fig. 17 . A relatively low overpotential of 307 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 64 mV/decade demonstrated the excellent OER activity of NiCo LDH-NA, which originated from the synergistic effect of vertically oriented LDH nanoarrays with larger surface areas, open structure and rich active sites, together with the highly conductive carbon fiber paper substrate. Very recently, Liu et al. grew NiFe LDH on the conductive supports of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNT) film by a facile hydrothermal method to form an integrated flexible electrode for OER [105]. A small overpotential of 250 mV and a Tafel slope of 35 mV/decade attested an excellent OER activity and a rapid reaction kinetics, respectively. As already mentioned, an efficient interfacial electron coupling between LDH and SWNT is very beneficial in enhancing the electrocatalytic activity. Herein, the in-situ growth of LDH nanoplates on 3D supports could improve the OER catalytic activity by increasing the active sites of LDHs, facilitating the electron transport, and accelerating mass transportation. Furthermore, the in-situ growth of LDH nanoplates on 3D supports could improve the structure stability, leading to the favorable durability of the electrocatalysts for practical application. 4 Conclusions In summary, this review highlights recent advances on LDH based materials for the electrocatalytic applications, mainly focusing on the water oxidation. LDH materials exhibited distinct features such as the tunable ratio of divalent/trivalent cations, exchangeable anions, and adjustable interlayer spacing. Furthermore, LDH materials could be exfoliated to single-layer nanosheets to enhance its electrocatalytic activity. However, low electrical conductivity posed a limiting factor for employing LDH materials as electrocatalysts. Therefore, great efforts have been made to improve its conductivity such as hetero-assembly with conductive 2D materials (graphene, rGO, and so on), growth on the 1D/3D conductive materials (CNT, Fe foam, Ni foam, carbon foam, etc.), and decoration with nanoparticles. Development of LDH composites with new compositions and new structures, e.g., by choosing and incorporating more electroactive elements, may be another way to achieve higher electrocatalytic activity. As a general strategy, the goal is to obtain LDH-based highly efficient electrocatalysts through increasing the conductivity and number of active sites, as well as enhancing the intrinsic activity of each active site. Toward the realization of efficient energy conversion processes, there are still many challenges ahead regarding the design and synthesis of LDH-based nonprecious metal electrocatalysts. Future devotion should be directed to optimize and integrate the advantages of LDHs with other complementing functional materials for harvesting maximum synergistic effect. Eng. 6 2018 2911 2915 Xiaolong Deng is an assistant Professor of the School of Physics and Technology at the University of Jinan. He graduated from Northwestern Polytechnical University with a B.Sc in 2006, and received an M.Eng from Shanghai University in 2009. He received a PhD from Konkuk University in 2013. Dr Deng's research interests focus on the synthesis and characterization of advanced sub-micro/nanomaterials for photo/electrocatalysis, conversion and energy storage applications. Jinzhao Huang is an associated Professor of the School of Physics and Technology at University of Jinan. He graduated from Linyi University with a BSc in 2003. He received a PhD from Beijing Jiaotong University in 2008. He has been a visiting scholar in the National Institute for Materials Science (in 2017). Dr Huang's research interests focus on electrochemical energy storage and conversions. Xijin Xu received his PhD degree in 2007 from the Institute of Solid State Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. During the following years, he worked in Nanyang Technological University in Singapore, National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS), and Australia. He started his research career at the University of Jinan as a full professor from 2011, and his research mainly focuses on functional micro/nano-materials and devices, including the constructions and applications of functional catalytic material, optoelectronic materials, especially on their applications in solar cells, supercapacitors, lithium-ion batteries and gas sensors. Renzhi Ma is a group leader of Functional Nanomaterials Group at the International Center for Materials Nanoarchitectonics (MANA), National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS), Japan. He received his PhD in Materials Processing Engineering from Beijing Tsinghua University in 2000. He worked as a postdoc for three years before becoming a staff researcher at NIMS in 2004. His work focuses on the synthetic chemistry of inorganic 1D nanotubes and 2D nanosheets, and advanced energy storage/conversion materials. Takayoshi Sasaki is the director of International Center for Materials Nanoarchitectonics (MANA), NIMS. He received his PhD in Chemistry from the University of Tokyo in 1985. Since 1980, he has worked for the National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM, now NIMS), Japan. In 2009, he was appointed as a NIMS fellow. His recent interest has focused on 2D nanosheets obtained by delaminating layered materials.

coredata.dc:description: Layered double hydroxides (LDHs), a class of anionic clays consisting of brucite-like host layers and interlayer anions, have been widely investigated in the last decade due to their promising applications in many areas such as catalysis, ion separation and adsorption. Owing to the highly tunable composition and uniform distribution of metal cations in the brucite-like layers, as well as the facile exchangeability of intercalated anions, LDHs can be modified and functionalized to form various nanostructures/composites through versatile processes such as anion intercalation and exfoliation, decoration of nanoparticles, self-assembly with other two-dimensional (2D) materials, and controlled growth on conductive supports (e.g., nanowire arrays, nanotubes, 3D foams). In this article, we briefly review the recent advances on both the LDH nanostructures and functionalized composites toward the applications in energy conversion, especially for water oxidation.
